com.lfscheidegger.jfacet

Class Drawable

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.lfscheidegger.jfacet.Drawable
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public final class Drawable
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Drawable objects represent things that Scene instances can draw. They contain all necessary geometrical information (in the form of a Geometry object), as well as VecLike objects representing the geometry's fully transformed position, and final per-fragment color.

    jfacet maintains a separation between the specification of a geometrical object (represented by a Geometry object) and the drawing of that object (represented by a Drawable). This allows you to specify different ways of drawing the same geometry, by assigning different VecLike objects for vertex positions and fragment colors to a Geometry, obtaining different instances of Drawable.

    In order to draw an object, jfacet tells the GPU to transform the raw vertex coordinates supplied to a Geometry by the first VecLike expression passed in to Drawable's constructor. It does the same for per-fragment colors, using the second VecLike passed in. As an example, consider a Geometry that contains raw vertex data for a single, red, triangle. In order to obtain its Drawable, you simply instantiate it: 

       Geometry triangleGeometry; // contains geometry for a single, red, triangle
   Drawable triangleDrawable = new Drawable(
     triangleGeometry,
     triangleGeometry.getVertices2(),
     triangleGeometry.getColors3());
    As a convenience, you can also obtain a Drawable directly from a Geometry: 
       Drawable triangleDrawable = triangleGeometry.getDrawable(
     triangleGeometry.getVertices2(),
     triangleGeometry.getColors3());
    This demonstrates the basics of Drawable, but jfacet supports a lot more power and flexibility. We can illustrate this by scaling the triangle from the previous example. If we want to render that triangle, but to half its size, we can use an Expression to help us: 
       // returns a new Vec3 that is half the size of the original
   Vec3 scaledVertexPosition = triangleGeometry.getVertices3().times(0.5f);

   Drawable triangleDrawable = triangleGeometry.getDrawable(
     scaledVertexPosition,
     triangleGeometry.getColors3());
    Expression objects can be combined in virtually infinite ways to completely customize the drawing of Drawable objects. They support most built-in GPU functionality, texture lookups, and even user input. Their combinations constitute the majority of the power behind jfacet (for more details, see the documentation for Expression).

    • Constructor Detail

      • Drawable

        public Drawable(Geometry geometry,
        VecLike vertexPosition,
        VecLike fragmentColor)
        Default constructor.
        Parameters:
        geometry - A Geometry with the geometric information (vertex positions, colors, normals, etc.) for this Drawable
        vertexPosition - A VecLike object encoding the fully transformed vertex position for this Drawable
        fragmentColor - A VecLike object encoding the final, per fragment color for this Drawable

    • Method Detail

      • getGeometry

        public Geometry getGeometry()
        Gets the Geometry associated with this Drawable.
        Returns:
        The Geometry containing the geometrical information for this Drawable

      • getVertexPosition

        public VecLike getVertexPosition()
        Gets the VecLike object used to transform vertex positions into their final, drawable positions.

        Drawable draws its contents by transforming the raw vertex coordinates passed in to the constructor (in a Geometry) using a VecLike object. This method returns that object.

        Returns:
        The VecLike object used to transform raw vertex positions into final positions for drawing

      • getFragmentColor

        public VecLike getFragmentColor()
        Gets the VecLike object whose value is used as the final per-fragment color for this Drawable.

        Drawable colors fragments that it draws using the value of this VecLike. For example: to draw a solid red object, you pass a new Vec3(1, 0, 0) into Drawable's constructor. This method returns that expression.

        Returns:
        The VecLike object that represents the final, per-fragment color for this Drawable

      • build

        public void build()
        Builds this Drawable, making it ready for drawing.

        Before Drawable objects can be drawn, jfacet needs to transform its vertex position and fragment color VecLike objects into GPU code, and load that code into the GPU. This method does exactly that, and must be called before drawing can occur. Typically, however, you do not need to call this manually. When you add Drawable objects to a Scene, and use FacetRenderer for displaying your graphics, this method gets called automatically for you.

        This method can only be called once a valid OpenGL context exists. Multiple calls to this method do nothing.

      • isBuilt

        public boolean isBuilt()
        Returns if this Drawable is built.

        Drawable objects must be built before they can be used for drawing. The process of building them generates GPU code for the object being drawn, and loads that code into the GPU. This method returns true if the build process is complete (see build()).

        Returns:
        true if this Drawable is built, false otherwise

      • run

        public void run()
        Draws this object.

        A call to run() immediately draws this object into the current OpenGL context. Typically, you don't need to call this manually - it is done for you in FacetRenderer. However, if you are implementing your own android.opengl.GLSurfaceView.Renderer, you'll want to have it call this method.

        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
